posts.name: Elijah Beard
posts.cooked: Our goal is to use a REV Through-Bore Encoder to go to a position with our intake. The problem is that we are using Talon SRXs to drive 775s and the Position Control will not work directly with the through bore encoders. An issue this causes is that to hold a position I would have to make sure the command runs constantly with percent output to make sure the PID is always going to the setpoint (which is a problem is we want to use the subsystem with another command). Is there a way to make it so that I would only need to call a PID set command once to hold? Thank you!

posts.name: Kevin Furlong
posts.cooked:
It obviously depends on what you’re trying to do with both commands. If each command isn’t utilizing the same functionality of the subsystem, you could consider splitting it into two separate subsystems or removing the subsystem “requirement” from one of the commands.

Last year we had an arm with a tiltable “wrist” at the end. We wanted to manually adjust positions of both with joysticks and have positions settable with a button press. We set our default command to take joystick values for the arm and the wrist and send them to functions within the subsystem that would decide how to deal with them. If the joystick values were above a deadband, it would apply that power to motors, if not then it would set the output to a value from a PID controller. We could update the setpoint with buttons or it would just hold that last manual position.

posts.name: Elijah Beard
posts.cooked: Alright after brainstorming some more, would making an instant command and adding .repeatedly work in this case? My only issue is that I need to make sure the command is interrupted when another instance of the Instant Command is called. Since the Instant Command does not have any requirements I do not know if that work. Would the command Scheduler handle that for me? Thank you!

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
You could use the periodic method to calculate the PID output and apply that to the method, and the command simply change the set point. You just have to be careful to make sure the two commands wouldn’t run at the same time causing the output to be set multiple times per loop, which could cause hard oscillations in the motor.

This is how the PIDSubsystem works

posts.name: Elijah Beard
posts.cooked: Oh that is smart and easily doable I didn’t think of that. I will for sure try this. Thank you for you help!

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
ebear11:

(which is a problem is we want to use the subsystem with another command)

While I haven’t seen your code, this is a warning sign: your single subsystem might be better off as two subsystems.

posts.name: Elijah Beard
posts.cooked: Right now I am just writing the code prototype and am trying to find structure. What I meant was if I want to hold the intake at a certain level it requires constantly running code and if another command is called it would cancel the hold but it needs to do other things while holding. Arch’s method seems to be exactly what I was seeking.

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
ebear11:

but it needs to do other things while holding.

Yes, this is what I am talking about.  What other things do you want to do while holding that should not replace that hold command?

posts.name: Elijah Beard
posts.cooked: Well if it’s one subsystem then any other command requiring the intake subsytem would cancel the hold on the intake because, without the position set being compatible with the through bore encoders, I have to run the set command with percentages instead and another command needing, as an example, to run the intake itself to take in notes. While I could make another subsystem just for the lift I feel as though the solution to make it run in the period section would be better for the structure of the code. With that, I can just make a command that sets a variable in the subsytem and the arm would just go to that variable. If this way does not work then I will resort to multiple subsystems for the intake. I would just like to avoid it for structures sake.

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
WPILib’s command structure is set up to expect that this would be two subsystems, for example:

Intake - controls the motors that move the game pieces

Arm - controls the motors that pivot the arm

While you could combine it into one subsystem, you’re going to have to fight the libraries multiple times and in multiple places to get it to work.  Some of those might occur when you’re time-constrained at competition.  I recommend coding it in the more conventional way, even if it seems odd right now.
